when I think about the US in that era, I think about the rise of foxnews, 2A extremism, and the increasing promotion of populists as "useful idiots" by the republicans.

reply_context.text: During this same time period the United States invested in, built, and further incentivized the most effective propaganda machines ever created. Those same people now control the corporations building AI. Which is neat.

posts.text: This is the correct framing, thank you.

reply_context.text: "What if I told you there was a simple, safe, & effective treatment to vastly reduce the risk of suicidal ideation among one of the most vulnerable group of children & teens? You'd be pretty stoked, I would think."

posts.text: "What if I told you there was a simple, safe, & effective treatment to vastly reduce the risk of suicidal ideation among one of the most vulnerable group of children & teens? You'd be pretty stoked, I would think."

if MAC theory is correct, we should be able to construct training objectives that induce simulated agents to evolve behavioral policies that mimic morality.

Correlation doesn't imply causation, but it does wag its eyebrows suggestively while pointing and shouting "hey look over there!"

reply_context.text: It's a good approach for hypothesis generation. We have the tools to build experiments out of this sort of thing, I just haven't seen it done yet. A premise of MAC theory is a causal mechanism grounded in game theory: ...

posts.text: It's a good approach for hypothesis generation. We have the tools to build experiments out of this sort of thing, I just haven't seen it done yet. A premise of MAC theory is a causal mechanism grounded in game theory: ...

reply_context.text: yes, i talk a bit about this kind of approach in the podcast and express skepticism.

reply_context.text: according to the letter of the law, it's actually illegal to try and launch a coup in both Brazil and the US, formally speaking (shocking!). yet the formal levers of power operated very differently in response to a coup attempt there than here. food for thought
